visa_free.notes: Passport must be valid for at least 6 months upon entry.

tourism.extra_notes: Double-check entry rules if you plan to stay close to the 90-day limit or do multiple entries.

business.extra_notes: Some business activities may require invitations or registrations; check with the consulate if you’re doing meetings or events.

tourism.extra_notes: Make sure you have proof of onward travel and enough funds for your stay.

business.extra_notes: If you’re attending conferences or meetings, bring invitation letters or company documents in case immigration asks.

visa_on_arrival.notes: Visa on arrival granted upon payment of fee.

tourism.extra_notes: Have hotel booking, return ticket, and proof of funds ready at the visa counter.

visa_on_arrival.notes: Fee may apply; proof of funds may be requested.

tourism.extra_notes: Keep accommodation details and a rough itinerary ready in case border officers ask.

business.extra_notes: For repeated business visits or longer stays, check if a pre-arranged visa is better than relying on visa on arrival.

tourism.extra_notes: Make sure the passport details match exactly what you enter in the e-visa form to avoid check-in issues.

business.extra_notes: You may need an invitation letter or company documents for business e-visas; check the official portal requirements.

study.extra_notes: Longer study programs often require a regular student visa instead of a simple e-visa; always confirm with the embassy or school.

e_visa.notes: E-visa required, processed through official portal.

tourism.extra_notes: Most e-visas are approved within a few days, but don’t leave it for the last 48 hours before your flight.

business.extra_notes: Carry printed copies of your e-visa approval and any invitation or conference documents for immigration.

visa_required.notes: Tourist visa must be obtained from the U.S. embassy prior to travel.

tourism.extra_notes: Interview wait times can be long. Check available appointment dates early and don’t book non-refundable tickets before you get the visa.

business.extra_notes: Have strong documentation of your job, company ties, and the purpose of the trip to improve your chances.

study.extra_notes: You need an I-20 or DS-2019 from your school. Book your appointment as soon as you receive your documents because student visa seasons are busy.

work.extra_notes: Most work visas require an approved petition before the embassy appointment. Timelines depend heavily on the employer and visa category.

visa_required.notes: Tourist visa must be obtained from the Gaelle Land embassy prior to travel.

tourism.extra_notes: Make sure you bring proof that you are the true ruler of Gaelle Land. Bonus points for creative supporting documents.
For peak seasons (summer, Christmas, New Year), apply even earlier because appointments and processing can be slower.

business.extra_notes: Have clear documents from your company and the German partner (invitation, meeting schedule, etc.).

study.extra_notes: Long-term study often needs a national (D-type) visa, not just a short-stay Schengen. Start early once you receive your admission letter.

work.extra_notes: Work visas usually require a signed contract, recognition of qualifications, and sometimes approvals from German authorities before the visa is issued.
